docs.lead_paragraph: In the coming months, Medicare will start taking patient satisfaction into account when reimbursing hospitals.

headline.seo: Patients’ Grades to Affect Hospitals’ Medicare Reimbursements
headline.main: Test for Hospital Budgets: Are the Patients Pleased?
headline.print_headline: Test for Hospital Budgets: Are the Patients Pleased?

docs.abstract: Winning praise from patients has become pressing issue for hospitals nationwide as Medicare prepares to start taking patient satisfaction into account when arranging reimbursement payments; shift is part of changes mandated by Affordable Care Act.
docs.snippet: In the coming months, Medicare will start taking patient satisfaction into account when reimbursing hospitals.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: Treatment once meant a month of intravenous medicines that could cause other damage and were hard to administer in remote hospitals.

headline.seo: Test Seeks Drugs to Fight Parasitic Kala Azar Disease
headline.main: Kala Azar: Four-Year Test Seeks Better Ways to Treat a Persistent Disease Spread by Sand Flies
headline.print_headline: Kala Azar: Four-Year Test Seeks Better Ways to Treat A Persistent Disease Spread by Sand Flies

docs.abstract: Governments of India and Bangladesh, along with coalition of medical organizations, announce four-year test of drugs to treat parasitic disease known as kala azar.
docs.snippet: Treatment once meant a month of intravenous medicines that could cause other damage and were hard to administer in remote hospitals.

docs.lead_paragraph: Prescriptions drugs are a growing threat to unknowing or experimenting children. And budget cuts threaten the centers themselves.

headline.seo: Poison Control Centers Facing Greater Risks
headline.main: Poison Centers Facing Greater Risks All Around
headline.print_headline: Poison Centers Facing Greater Risks All Around

docs.abstract: Dr Perri Klass 18 and Under column notes nationwide network of poison centers is under threat from state and federal budget cuts; contends centers are more important than ever due to proliferation of pharmaceutical products.
docs.snippet: Prescriptions drugs are a growing threat to unknowing or experimenting children. And budget cuts threaten the centers themselves.

docs.lead_paragraph: Modern treatments can do wonders if they are begun before the damage to the eye is irreversible.

headline.seo: Fast Action Can Save Sight if Retina Is Detached or Blocked
headline.main: Act Fast to Save Sight if Signs of Danger to the Retina Appear
headline.print_headline: Act Fast to Save Sight if Signs of Danger to the Retina Appear

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column notes modern treatments for retinal damage can be extremely successful if symptoms are caught early enough.
docs.snippet: Modern treatments can do wonders if they are begun before the damage to the eye is irreversible.

docs.lead_paragraph: When are floaters in your vision a sign of something worse?

headline.seo: Living With Floaters and Flashes in the Eye
headline.main: Floaters and Flashes, but Only a Preview
headline.print_headline: Floaters and Flashes, but Only a Preview

docs.abstract: Roving blotches in the field of vision known as 'floaters' can indicate conditions like detached retina and vitreus hemorrhage, and should be checked quickly by doctor.
docs.snippet: When are floaters in your vision a sign of something worse?

docs.lead_paragraph: According to a new study, freshmen actually gain an average of 2.5 to 3.5 pounds, and the weight gain has little to do with college attendance.

headline.seo: ‘Freshman 15’ Weight Gain? ‘Freshman 3’ May Be More Realistic
headline.main: Patterns: ‘Freshman 15’ Is a Myth, a Study Suggests
headline.print_headline: Patterns: ‘Freshman 15’ Is a Myth, a Study Suggests

docs.abstract: Study published in journal Social Science Quarterly finds college freshman gain average of 2.5 to 3.5 pounds, contradicting popular idea of the 'freshman 15;' Jay L Zagorsky of Ohio State is study's lead author.
docs.snippet: According to a new study, freshmen actually gain an average of 2.5 to 3.5 pounds, and the weight gain has little to do with college attendance.
